__data__.text:
Spring 2024 Reflection Report 
 Shashank V erma 
 sverma342@gatech.edu 
 Advisor: Dr . Ashok Goel 
 2024-05-03 
 Abstract 
 This  report  discusses  the  progress  I’ve  made  on  the  Project  Ivy  at  DILab  over  the  past 
 semester  from  onboarding  to  understanding  TMK  models  to  developing  TMK  models 
 for  new  skills  to  integrating  these  models  with  a  reasoning  agent  i.e.  MCM  to  iterating 
 over  and  documenting  the  reasoner’s  responses  to  sample  student  questions.  Finally  I 
 attempted  to  reconcile  Ivy’s  codebase  with  other  teams’  at  DILab  to  understand  and 
 learn from each other. 
 1. Project Description 
 The huge majority of online learning/classes in their current state is passive learning 
 by watching videos. Project Ivy aims to elevate the online education domain by 
 making learning constructive and interactive thereby helping students gain a deeper 
 understanding of the material and retain the knowledge better . Ivy’s goal is to do this 
 in a generalizable and scalable way by encoding a teacher ’s understanding of any 
 skill as a TMK model which guides a reasoning agent to interact with students and 
 answer their questions. The proof of concept for the project demonstrated improved 
 student performance and engagement  [1]  highlighting the importance and untapped 
 potential of AI in education. 
 2. My Role/Mini-Project 
 This was my first semester working on Ivy in DILab. I spent the first couple of weeks 
 onboarding and learning about what the team has done over the past semesters, 
 plan for the current semester , etc. Then I started working on developing a TMK 
 model for the problems of skill Classification as taught in the KBAI 
 (Knowledge-based AI) course. Once the symbolic and structural representation of 
 the model was ready and reviewed, I created JSON representations for the same. 
 This is the format in which the reasoning agent consumes the teacher ’s 
 understanding of the skill.

After this, I generated some sample questions to test out 
 the model and documented the responses I got. Then I tinkered with the JSON 
 representation and the codebase itself to iterate over and improve the responses

given by the agent. Finally I reconciled the Ivy codebase with that of SAMI (another 
 team in DILab) and found the answers to my questions improved slightly . 
 3. Accomplishments 
 3.1 Onboarding & Understanding TMK 
 Over the course of this quarter , I learnt a great deal of what it means to ground an AI 
 with “  understanding”  of the skill. This understanding of the skill allows the AI agent to 
 give responses which can evoke thought within the reader and equally importantly it 
 won’t give questionable or wrong answers. TMKL2 language, which is used to 
 generate the TMK models  [2]  , is the centerpiece of this knowledge based grounding 
 for the AI agent. 
 As such, I spent the first few weeks understanding the design of TMKL2 language 
 and how it captures the goal of a problem and its associated methods and 
 knowledge base. I also familiarised myself with the  Classification  skill taught in the 
 KBAI class for which I would be developing the TMK model. 
 3.2 TMK modeling 
 I spent the next few weeks developing the TMK model for various problems of the 
 Classification skill. I first created the  symbolic representation  and iterated on the 
 process, refining the model by gaining feedback from the team. I met with Spencer to 
 get his valuable insights on the thought process behind developing these models 
 and the fundamentals of TMK modeling. 
 Later , I translated the symbolic representation to the  structural representation  which 
 was subsequently translated to  programmatic representation  in JSON. 
 The TMKL2 tutorial  [3]  was an invaluable resource in gaining a holistic understanding 
 of the TMK model development process.
Fig. 1  - Complete symbolic representation of TMK model for Concept Hierarchies - Classification

3.3 Generating and refining responses 
 Once I had the my TMK model represented in JSON, I generated baseline 
 responses for some sample T ask/Method and Knowledge questions that a typical 
 student might have and recorded them  in the spreadsheet  and  presented  the team. 
 After looking at the loss patterns and brainstorming with the team, I refined the JSON 
 files to ensure that the model is able to better understand the relevance of the 
 document to the user query . That led to  better responses  mostly due to better 
 document matching. 
 I will continue to document further refinements to the responses. 
 3.4 Rebasing ivy branch to SAMI’ s setup 
 The codebases of Ivy and SAMI have diverged over the semesters. Given that SAMI 
 has had more success with their MCM+TMK agent, we wanted to see what the 
 differences are in the codebase and whether they would help Ivy as well including 
 but not limited to how the langchain (e.g. kmodel wasn’t present in Ivy previously) 
 are setup and which version of chatgpt model is deployed. 
 I created the  ivy_rebased  branch on github with this rebasing done. The main two 
 improvements I noticed after doing this were: 
 -  Final answer was more meaningful than before. In the previous setup we 
 used to get good intermediate answers but the final answer didn't do a good 
 job of summarizing it. 
 -  mmodel questions used to be bound to generating a state machine transition 
 based response, but that was no longer the case with the new setup. 
 Finally I started tinkering with the chains and configs to better understand the flow 
 and try out some ideas. The idea here is that the original codebase was developed 
 for SAMI’ s self explanation model and was later adapted with minimal changes for 
 Ivy. This means that we should be able to repurpose it to suit Ivy’ s usecase better via 
 better chain of thought prompting, dif ferent langchain setup, alternate document 
 classification, etc. 
 4. Reflection 
 4.1 Issues 
 TMK modeling was definitely a challenging task.

Reflection 
 4.1 Issues 
 TMK modeling was definitely a challenging task. There are multiple ways to go about 
 writing a TMK model for a problem which adds to the complexity . At the beginning of 
 the semester , I spent most of the time going over the Ivy Onboarding document  [5]  , 
 TMKL2 paper  [2]  as well as the GAIA paper  [4]  to gain an understanding of the workings

of TMK modeling as well as its applications. The existing couple of TMK models 
 developed by the team in previous semesters was pretty useful. Later in the 
 semester , the TMKL2 tutorial  [3]  proved to be an invaluable resource for solidifying 
 how-tos of the TMK modeling process. I iterated over my TMK model and got 
 feedback from the team and ultimately settled on a model that satisfied the 
 constraints and did the job. 
 While we were generating the responses and tweaking the contents in JSON files to 
 get better results, my task was also to derive inspiration from the SAMI team’ s setup. 
 I ran into multiple issues in reconciling the two codebases and required many 
 decisions to be made that ultimately helped me understand the codebase better . I 
 learnt how the dif ferent chains were setup e.g. kmodel, mmodel, etc, how we were 
 doing question classification, better understood chain of thought prompting, which 
 chatgpt model works best, etc. I included the kmodel for the new Ivy’ s setup since I 
 thought it made sense to have a dedicated chain for knowledge based questions. 
 Similarly , I decided to use  gpt-3.5-turbo-0125  chatgpt model even though I was 
 looking to ideally use the instruct model which is better suited for question/answer 
 situations. However , the endpoints we were using were only supported by the chat 
 model and weren’t compatible with the instruct model. Perhaps in future, I’ll look to 
 update the endpoints to work with the instruct model. 
 4.2 Process Improvement suggestions 
 I think we should modify all the TMK models that our team has produced to strictly 
 adhere to the TMKL2 language constructs (even though that would produce quite a 
 few duplicated pieces of logic/assertions). Currently all the models are loosely based 
 on the TMKL2, skipping some obvious transitions, sub-goal and sub-goal’ method 
 specifications, etc. I think that in addition to the TMKL2 paper and tutorial would be 
 sufficient for faster onboarding of new-comers to the team in future.

In a similar vein, I believe that we can create one-pagers for workings of MCM repo 
 once we’ve tackled more pressing issues and settled on the best configuration of our 
 reasoning agent. Continuing to document all such decisions we’ve made will also 
 ensure we don’t go investigating down the same road in future. 
 Perhaps once we develop Ivy to the point of answering episodic questions as well, 
 we can create a document/process for testing the validity of the TMK model that 
 would allow the model creator to iterate quickly and refine their models by looking at 
 how a reasoning agent is able to consume the model for the skill, what parts of the 
 model need more specification, etc. 
 4.3 What I learned 
 I learnt a great deal about modeling problems with TMKL2. Even after going over 
 existing TMK models and developing a TMK model of my own, there is still more to

be learnt about the process. I learnt the power and capabilities of TMKL2 as a 
 modeling language when working on my own model and the breadth of problems it 
 can model when looking at all the skills that have been modeled by our team. An 
 interesting find when working on JSON representations of Environment section was 
 adding enums to make it a  Concept  more concrete for the reasoner as shown below . 
 Fig. 2  - Definition of Concept “Percept” using enums which leads to better responses 
 The ideology of grounding LLMs is an active area of research and we’re trying to do 
 that via knowledge based AI which is pretty interesting to me. I also learnt a lot about 
 how we can use LLMs with LangChain and Chain-of-thought prompting  [6]  to get 
 astronomically better results than simply asking the LLM any given question. 
 Over the semester our team also went over Evaluation methods paper  [7]  and 
 brainstormed about which metrics we want to use for our project for the time being 
 for establishing benchmarks. 
 4.4 What worked and what didn’t work 
 I really liked how responsive the team is and how passionate everyone is about the 
 work. W e had multiple instances of teammates hopping on a VC to explain 
 something from TMK modeling ideas to MCM/Autogen demos. I also appreciate how

motivating our advisor Dr . Goel and Dr . Spencer are and it was interesting to hear 
 their back and forth on multiple topics and occasions. 
 Hearing the team present posters at AI-ALOE showcase and to a larger group of 
 faculties and hearing their excitement and discussion was also motivating for me. 
 It was a bit confusing at first to develop TMK models, however , that was to be 
 expected. The team being helpful didn’t let anyone get stuck and I was able to make 
 consistent progress. 
 5. Pointers 
 I used the shared DILab’ s github to add and make changes to my TMK JSON files, 
 MCM reasoning agent, LLM config, LangChain setup, etc. All my code is present on 
 the branch ivy_classification. Later when I rebased this to SAMI’ s branch, I added 
 another branch ivy_rebased which is now the latest setup I have. 
 The structural and symbolic representations of my TMK model along with any other 
 presentations I worked on are present on the Sharepoint under “Spring 2024” folder . 
 6. Conclusion 
 Overall, I’m very pleased to have been a part of DILab with a great advisor and team 
 members. I feel strongly about the mission statement of Ivy and would love to see it 
 revolutionise the use of AI in education. Looking forward to the upcoming phase of 
 Ivy. 
 References 
 [1]  R. Dass, D. Joyner , A. Goel, S. Rugaber , and C. Ou. Ivy poster: “in-video tutors: 
 Revisited and beyond”, 2023 
 [2]  S. Rugaber , “TMKL2 – A T eleological Language for Adapting Software” May 1 1, 
 2011 
 [3]  S. Rugaber , Tmkl2 tutorial, 2024

[4]  S. Rugaber , A. K. Goel, and L. Martie, “Gaia: A CAD environment for 
 model-based adaptation of game-playing software agents,” Procedia Computer 
 Science, vol. 16, pp. 29s–38, 2013. doi:10.1016/j.procs.2013.01.004 
 [5]  R. Dass, “Interactive V ideos – Onboarding Guide“, 2023 
 [6]  W ei et al., “Chain-of-Thought Prompting Elicits Reasoning in Large Language 
 Models”, 2023 
 [7]  Nauta et al., “From Anecdotal Evidence to Quantitative Evaluation Methods: A 
 Systematic Review on Evaluating Explainable AI”, 2023
